Major rebellions in well-governed kingdoms were rare—perhaps once or twice per reign, usually triggered by specific grievances (succession disputes, oppressive taxation, religious persecution, royal weakness).

Minor noble feuds were constant background noise in every medieval society—not threats to the crown, just the normal friction of armed aristocrats.

Plagues struck periodically—major outbreaks every 10-20 years after 1348, minor outbreaks more frequently.

Famines depended on weather—perhaps 1 in 5-7 years saw a bad harvest somewhere.

Conspiracies were common in unstable situations (disputed successions, weak kings, foreign rule) but rare when a strong king held undisputed power.

Decree Establishing the Regency Council of Castile

In the name of God Almighty, Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. Amen.

Juan, by the Grace of God King of Castile, León, Aragon, Naples, and Sicily, Defender of the Faith and Protector of Christendom, to all who read this decree, greeting and grace.

Preamble

Whereas the burdens of our office require our presence in distant lands for the defense of Christendom;

Whereas the governance of our realm of Castile must continue in our absence with wisdom and justice;

Whereas the concentration of such governance in a single hand has proven neither prudent nor in keeping with the ancient customs of our realm;

We do hereby establish, by our royal authority and with the counsel of our faithful subjects, a Council of Regency for the governance of Castile during such times as we are absent from the realm.

Article I: Composition

The Council of Regency shall consist of three members, each representing one of the estates of the realm:

Firstly, one member elected by the noble estate of the Cortes, from among their number;

Secondly, one member elected by the estate of the commons of the Cortes, from among their number;

Thirdly, one member elected by the ecclesiastical estate of the Cortes, from among their number.

Each estate shall determine its own representative by such method as that estate sees fit, provided that the selection is made during a lawfully assembled session of the Cortes.

Article II: Authority

The Council of Regency shall exercise the governance of Castile in the King's absence, with authority to:

Firstly, maintain the peace and administer justice throughout the realm;

Secondly, collect and disburse the ordinary revenues of the Crown according to established law and custom;

Thirdly, correspond with foreign powers on routine matters not touching upon war, alliance, or the succession;

Fourthly, make such appointments to minor offices as the administration of the realm requires;

Fifthly, execute such other duties as the proper governance of the realm demands.

Article III: Limitations

The Council of Regency shall NOT, without the express written consent of the King, undertake any of the following:

Firstly, declare war or conclude peace with any foreign power;

Secondly, negotiate treaties of alliance or marriage touching upon the royal house;

Thirdly, alter the laws or customs of the realm;

Fourthly, levy extraordinary taxation beyond that already approved by the Cortes;

Fifthly, make appointments to the great offices of state;

Sixthly, alienate any lands, castles, or revenues belonging to the Crown;

Seventhly, pardon crimes of treason, heresy, or lèse-majesté.

Article IV: Obedience to the Crown

The Council of Regency serves at the pleasure of the King and Queen. Its members are bound to obey all commands issued by the King, or by the Queen acting in the King's name. No act of the Council may contradict a direct royal instruction. The King retains the authority to overrule, modify, or annul any decision of the Council at any time, for any reason, without explanation.

The Queen, when present in Castile, shall be kept informed of all significant matters before the Council and may attend its deliberations at her pleasure. Her counsel shall be sought on all matters touching upon the royal household, the succession, or the welfare of the royal children.

Article V: Term and Election

Each member of the Council of Regency shall serve until the next lawful assembly of the Cortes, at which time all three positions shall be subject to election anew. No presumption of continuity shall attach to any member; each Cortes shall make its selections freely, whether to retain the current member or to select another.

The first election under this decree shall take place at the next assembly of the Cortes following the promulgation of this decree.

Article VI: Vacancy

Should any member of the Council die, become incapacitated, or be removed by royal command during their term, the remaining members shall continue to exercise the Council's authority until the relevant estate can select a replacement.
